What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:

options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I can now read
My level of reading and writing in Chinese drastically improved.
How to speak, read and write Chinese

I learned many new words, phrases, grammar points, and concepts in the Chinese language that not only offer me a better understanding of Chinese culture but also greatly improved my speaking and writing abilities.
Skills necessary to comprehend and use Chinese at a more nuanced level through learning new vocabulary for different contexts, and gaining a better understanding of Chinese culture.
A strong foundation in Chinese, reinforcing skills.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lots of work, I wish there was more time between assignments.

The course's strength was its ability to focus on the skills students need to have a proficient Chinese level. I thought it was really good at teaching the important aspects of how to speak Chinese. A weakness is that it it online since it is harder to practice oral skills.

Strengths: Great Professor (Liu Laoshi was very enthusiastic, organized, and a fast grader) This class really teaches you how to speak, read, and write Chinese even if it's a lot of work. I don't know if this is a weakness, but I think L4 vocabulary was much more difficult than L3, so it took a lot more time to understand the grammar. Also, essays were really difficult to write and you usually only had like 3 days to write it. All in all, this is a very worthwhile class.

Strengths include the liveliness of our instructor, Professor Liu, and the interesting subject material. A slight weakness was the relative monotony of some of the daily vocabulary and grammar drilling, but these were all necessary in order to master the subject material so I do not consider to big of a drawback.
Course was very well organized with clear deadlines and expectations.
Strengths are that it's super intense, but weaknesses are that it is not clear from the beginning what the expectations are/how to access materials.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not much could  be fixed

In order to have more engagement, students would unmute and practice speaking verbally together. However, this was difficult with the pandemic since the internet/background could be a problem/distraction.

Virtual class was not too different from what I would imagine an in person class would look like in terms of the activities done, with the only exception being having more time to converse with classmates in Chinese. The lectures, q&a structure, and occasional breakout rooms all helped to keep the class engaging and give us many opportunities to practice our Chinese skills.
If classes could be more planned out and less discussion!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Only if you must learn chinese.
Yes, if the student is looking to improve their Chinese skills, I think that this course really delivered.
For sure! Chinese is great to learn, especially if your whole family speaks it.
Yes - if you feel you are capable of understanding Chinese quite well and have some good Chinese language sense but are looking to improve on grammar and vocabulary, this class is for you.

Yes, I would highly recommend it to any heritage speaker that believes they're around the intermediate level. The class does seem to emphasize speaking and reading more than writing, so I would advise students to be prepared to practice handwriting Chinese independently of what's assigned in class if they need extra practice on it.
Yes, I'd recommend this to anyone who is interested in Chinese, and the heritage track is very helpful!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
Tutorial session with a graduate student
Aynchronous discussions on Thursdays
